title: Bill Gatewood
text:
William Miller "Big Bill" Gatewood (August 22, 1881 – December 8, 1962) was an American <a href="Negro%20league%20baseball">Negro league baseball</a> <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> and <a href="manager%20%28baseball%29">manager</a> for several years before the founding of the first <a href="Negro%20National%20League%20%281920%E2%80%931931%29">Negro National League</a>, and in its first few seasons. He pitched for the <a href="Leland%20Giants">Leland Giants</a>, <a href="Chicago%20Giants">Chicago Giants</a>, <a href="St.%20Paul%20Colored%20Gophers">St. Paul Colored Gophers</a>, <a href="Chicago%20American%20Giants">Chicago American Giants</a>, New York <a href="Lincoln%20Giants">Lincoln Giants</a>, <a href="Cuban%20X-Giants">Cuban X-Giants</a>, <a href="Philadelphia%20Giants">Philadelphia Giants</a>, <a href="Brooklyn%20Royal%20Giants">Brooklyn Royal Giants</a>, <a href="St.%20Louis%20Giants">St. Louis Giants</a>, <a href="Indianapolis%20ABCs">Indianapolis ABCs</a>, <a href="Detroit%20Stars">Detroit Stars</a>, <a href="St.%20Louis%20Stars%20%28baseball%29">St. Louis Stars</a>, <a href="Toledo%20Tigers">Toledo Tigers</a>, <a href="Milwaukee%20Bears">Milwaukee Bears</a>, <a href="Memphis%20Red%20Sox">Memphis Red Sox</a>, <a href="Atlantic%20City%2C%20New%20Jersey">Atlantic City</a> <a href="Bacharach%20Giants">Bacharach Giants</a>, and <a href="Birmingham%20Black%20Barons">Birmingham Black Barons</a>.
Career.
Sportswriter Harry Daniels named Gatewood to his 1909 "All American Team."
In the first week of June in 1920, at age 38, Gatewood left the <a href="St.%20Louis%20Giants">St. Louis Giants</a> and joined <a href="Tenny%20Blount">Tenny Blount</a>'s team, the <a href="Detroit%20Stars">Detroit Stars</a>. Part-way through the second season, he moved on to the <a href="Cuban%20Stars%20%28West%29">Cuban Stars</a>.
A 6'7" tall <a href="spitball">spitball</a> pitcher, Gatewood was a first line pitcher in Blackball's pre-league days, and pitched the first <a href="no-hitter">no-hitter</a> in NNL league play, beating the <a href="Cuban%20Stars%20%28West%29">Cincinnati Cuban Stars</a> on June 6, 1921. As his pitching skills deteriorated, he remained in the game as a manager.
Gatewood managed the <a href="St.%20Louis%20Stars%20%28baseball%29">St. Louis Stars</a> and <a href="Birmingham%20Black%20Barons">Birmingham Black Barons</a>. He is credited with giving Negro leagues great James <a href="Cool%20Papa%20Bell">Cool Papa Bell</a> his famous nickname, and for convincing him to learn to switch hit in order to take advantage of his speed. Gatewood is also credited with teaching <a href="Satchel%20Paige">Satchel Paige</a> his "hesitation pitch" while managing him in Birmingham.
After Gatewood died, he was buried in an unmarked grave and did not receive a proper headstone until a <a href="Society%20for%20American%20Baseball%20Research">Society for American Baseball Research</a> group called the <a href="Negro%20Leagues%20Baseball%20Grave%20Marker%20Project">Negro Leagues Baseball Grave Marker Project</a> installed a proper gravestone in 2010. Gatewood's grave did not have a headstone for about 48 years.
